Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.

Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields involves the group of automorphisms of the splitting field that fix the base field. These automorphisms form a group under the operation of composition. For any set of operations to form a group, they must satisfy certain properties: closure, associativity, identity, and inverses.

The Associative Law specifically states that a law of composition on a set is associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c$ in the set. This law is crucial for the definition of a group because one of the fundamental properties of a group is that the operation must be associative.

Therefore, the concept of the Associative Law is inherently required for the definition of a Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields, as the group of automorphisms must satisfy the associative property to be considered a group. Without the Associative Law, the set of automorphisms would not necessarily form a group, and thus the concept of the Galois Group would not be well-defined.
